Documentation Reference

IMPORTANT
All provided commands have to be executed from the root of the project.
To make the commands easier to read the path to the executable gets replaced with the command name.
For example:
Packages/docfx.console.2.59.4/tools/docfx.exe gets replaced with docfx
So in case you want to use the bundled docfx:
instead of a command like docfx help use Packages/docfx.console.2.59.4/tools/docfx.exe help

General

The documentation for this project is made with DocFx
DocFx is bundled as a NuGet package development dependency within this project.

Your IDE should automatically pick up the dependency under packages.json and install the DocFx tool for you.
Afterwards the tool can be found under Packages/docfx.console.2.59.4

However, in case the tool does not get installed you can also install it manually from here.
It is advised to use the same version used within this project.
You can also install it via a package manager like Chocolatey.
In that case you can also use the provided commands as is.

How to build the documentation

To build the projects documentation execute docfx docfx.json This will create the obj and _site directories at the root of the project, which hold cache files and the built documentation.

Afterwards, to host and view the documentation locally append the serve flag docfx docfx.json --serve

Troubleshooting Sometimes it can be necessary to clear the generated files before creating new ones.
This can be due to conflicting metadata, but can easily be resolved by deleting the obj directory.

How to create a remote public documentation (e.g. for GitHub pages)

The documentation can also be remotely hosted via GitHub pages.
Once a new release has been made, the remote public documentation should be updated as well.
For that we generate the documentation in a new docs directory.
docfx docfx.json -o ./docs/

This directory can then be used to generate the remote documentation pages.
